Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \), showing simple harmonic motion in the complex plane, where \\( \omega \) is a constant frequency. Let's investigate the effect of an integral transformation \\( T(z) = \int_0^t z(\tau) e^{-i\omega \tau} d\tau \) applied to z(t).

If an additional damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) (where \\( \alpha \) is a constant) is introduced at time t = t1, modifying the function to \\( z(t) = e^{-\alpha t}e^{i\omega t} \\), will the transformation \\( T(z) \\) at time T > t1 reflect only the changes due to \\( \alpha \) and not \\( \omega \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) adds to the effect of \\( \omega \\) on the function \\( z(t) \\). The transformation \\( T(z) \\) at time T registers effects of both the frequency \\( \omega \\) and the damping \\( \alpha \\), altering its computation and the resulting integral. Both parameters shape the outcome.
